name: TheAtlantic
text: "It is tempting to say that Sessions and Barr were both Trumpists avant la lettre, but their eventual conflicts with him show there was no such thing: Trumpism is a cult of personality, and policy is always an afterthought," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/kWRSvaN1pu

name: TheAtlantic
text: John le Carré "wasn’t just a medicine man of the English imagination; he was a stylist, too," James Parker writes. "Perfectly weighted descriptive sentences, with just a flicker of dour lyricism." https://t.co/FmZfGl5hGk

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Cleveland’s baseball team has announced that it will drop the name “Indians.”

In November, Hannah Giorgis reported on what the similar rebranding of the Washington Football Team meant for Native American advocates—and for fans: https://t.co/BRtI3tMlmb

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Many court systems lack basic data about themselves," Michael P. Donnelly and Pierre H. Bergeron write. https://t.co/AQ0YGJbVsm

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If Jill Biden wants to flaunt her Ed.D., who is Joseph Epstein to object?" asks @gcaw: https://t.co/dICS3Da0li

name: TheAtlantic
text: This spring, thousands of researchers paused their projects in order to study the deadly disease, COVID-izing their disciplines. The latest Atlantic Daily: https://t.co/z05kKYmYev

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TomMcTague: To be English is to always feel a little bit out of place, even in England. John le Carré helped us better understand why, allowing us to spy on ourselves. https://t.co/JerM5hKcCk

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: More than most, four men shaped the oft-cited “strategic tensions” over the world’s most important body of water. @DanielYergin writes of the ghosts who haunt the South China Sea: https://t.co/GEb0aqEeSJ

text: "The Texas politician has built his career on using ... defeats to rally support. And losing this lawsuit—his highest-profile setback to date—might have been just what he needed as his own legal problems continue to mount," @CarlosASanchez writes: https://t.co/rayKtMO7ZY

text:
RT @YAppelbaum: "Somewhere along the way, Facebook decided that it needed not just a very large user base, but a tremendous one, unprecedented in size."

What if Facebook is just too big? Thought-provoking read from @AdrienneLaF

https://t.co/ISuETQXCqv

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: "The standoff over the South China Sea thus has many levels of complexity. It is not simply about one body of water, or a single boundary." — @DanielYergin https://t.co/MRcm7apO0z

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: I’ve come to realize that Facebook is not a media company. It’s a Doomsday Machine. Here’s my story about what that means, and what we should do about it: https://t.co/WwVBLxmCwO  (7/7)

text: The year 2020 has given more to the authors of history textbooks than it has to the writers of diaries. @jpinsk chronicles the year we lost: https://t.co/f83aYvG73V

name: TheAtlantic
text: Facebook isn’t just having a bad week, or month, or year, or decade. It’s doing exactly what it was built for, @AdrienneLaF writes. https://t.co/4luP9uLsm7
